Eisenhower's 75th
By BOB BUCHANAN
Tomorrow afternoon The
Johns Hopkins Universir
Alumni Association will sponsor
the celebration of the 75th
birthday of Milton S.
Eisenhower, who was twice
President of the University.
Beginning at 4:30 p.m. in the
lower quad, a buffet supper will
be served. Included will be such
entrees as hot dogs and
hamburgers, with ice ,cold beer
and drinks to complement the
menu of the affair. At the prior
request of Eisenhower, the
celebration will move at 6:15
p.m. up 33rd Street to Memorial
Stadium . The party will arrive ir
time to watch the Baltimore
Orioles game.
Long a fan of the Baltimore
Orioles, Eisenhower is, in the
words of Stanley Blumberg,
organizer of the event, "a
baseball fanatic."
"He is the only person who
ever received a gold lifetime pass
from the Orioles," he added.
• In this light, it is an added
attraction that former Oriole
pitcher Dave Leonard, a Hopkins
graduate, will be on hand for the
festivities.
Formerly President of Kansas
State and Pennsylvania State
Universities, and brother of the
late President of the United
States, Dwight D. Eisenhower,
Milton Eisenhower was President
of Johns Hopkins from 1956 to
1967 and again in the interim
period 1971 to 1972.
Eisenhower, nationally and
internationally prominent, was
chairman for the President's
Commission on Violence in 1970
and was the troubleshooter for

Milton Eisenhower
three President's in the area of
Latin American affairs, advising
his brother, John F. Kennedy
and Johnson in this area.
Perhaps of more significance
to Hopkins students however, is
the key role Eisenhower played
in the improvement of
undergraduate studies here. In his
first term as President of the
University, Eisenhower was
responsible for financing the
construction of many of the
newer buildings which bears his
name.
In the interim year 1971-72,
he laid the groundwork for the
proposal which saw the
University allow for the inclusion
of four young trustees on the
Board of Trustees.
In addition, Eisenhower saw to
it that the now completed
Student Union was financed.
"More than any other man he
made sure the finances were
found for the Hopkins Union,"
stated Blumberg.

Colmers discusses ombudsman position, duties
The following is an interview with
John Colmers, this year's Student
Ombudsman, the official liaison between

with the appointment of Shep Hoffman
by Dean Owen. The interview was
conducted Wednesday, September 11,

Colmers will deal this year as
Ombudsman—pass-fail policy, course
offerings, and student interaction with
the Deans.
News-Letter: In what areas do you

Ombudsman?

concerning work with the curriculum and
changes in the'academic prop-am.

really have as regards the Deans and their
decisions?

just somebody with easy access to the
.Deans. Any weight that the office carries
.comes from how effectively I can express
the needs of the students to the Deans.

they attribute any importance to what
you say?
Colmers: I think if a matter is not
trivial and I present it sincerely, they'll
listen. But then again, what they do is a
different story. I know that the Deans
won't be in favor of everything that I'm
in favor of. But I'm sure that I'll be
listened to on just about any topic.
N-L: Do you have any regrets that
students were not allowed any
participation in the selection of .the
Ombudsman?
Colmers: I certainly think that in the
future—nothing can be done now—I'd
welcome as much participation on the
part of the students as the Deans will
permit.
N-L: In making decisions, -whose
perspective will you adopt—that of the
Deans, whose office pays your salary, or
that ofthe students?

I'll have a student interests foremost in

try to bring the point of view of someone

Fraternities do not die. Even

N-L INTERVIEW

Colmers discusses ombudsman position, duties
The following is an interview with
John Colmers, this year's Student
Ombudsman, the official liaison between
students and Deans Owen and Suskind.
The office was established two years ago
with the appointment of Shep Hoffman
by Dean Owen. The interview was
conducted Wednesday, September 11,
and concerns those issues with which
Colmers will deal this year as
Ombudsman—pass-fail policy, course
offerings, and student interaction with
the Deans.
News-Letter: In what areas do you
plan to concentrate this academic year as
Ombudsman?
Colmers: Two areas. The first is dealing
directly with students and their academic
problems, the second is in broader areas
concerning work with the curriculum and
changes in the'academic prop-am.
N-L: How much influence do you
really have as regards the Deans and their
decisions?
• Colmers: I'm really nothing more than
just somebody with easy access to the
.Deans. Any weight that the office carries
.comes from how effectively I can express
the needs of the students to the Deans.
N-L: But will they listen to you? Will
they attribute any importance to what
you say?
Colmers: I think if a matter is not
trivial and I present it sincerely, they'll
listen. But then again, what they do is a
different story. I know that the Deans
won't be in favor of everything that I'm
in favor of. But I'm sure that I'll be
listened to on just about any topic.
N-L: Do you have any regrets that
students were not allowed any
participation in the selection of .the
Ombudsman?
Colmers: I certainly think that in the
future—nothing can be done now—I'd
welcome as much participation on the
part of the students as the Deans will
permit.
N-L: In making decisions, -whose
perspective will you adopt—that of the
Deans, whose office pays your salary, or
that ofthe students?
Colmers: No question. Being a student,
I'll have a student interests foremost in
mind. That's what I bring to the office. I
try to bring the point of view of someone

John Colmers
who is a student at•Hopkins and has had
problems with the system.
N-L: Referring back to your plans for
this year, what specific changes are you
going to work for?
•
Colmers: I have no specific plans yet,
but if I see something that's obviously a
hindrance to students and has a broad
base of students against it, then I'll get to
work on it. I'm not going to sit back, if
students are clamoring for change, and
say "that's the way it is." As far as
academics go, the CUS [the Committee
on Undergraduate Studies] is the major
area for undergraduate input. I foresee.
myself workibg, with the undergraduates
on the CUS in whatever capacity I can.
N-L: Since the limits and powers of the
Ombudsman position have never' been
officially decided upon, much less 'set
down, are you going to expand upon the
powers Shep Hoffman exercised as
Ombudsman last year?
Colmers: I think I'd like to .see the

office be one that can work with the CUS
and the Student Council to bring about
academic change. I think I can bring to
the position my experience with the
Student Council and hopefully bring new
ideas to the front.
N-L: What is your opinion on the
pass-fail policy for first semester
freshman? Did you favor tile old
"airtight" policy or the new, more
flexible one?
Colmers: I think the old system was
too rigid. But the attempt to change it
last year was done in a bush league way.
The University had an obligation to the
students who started on the original
system. I think the new system for this
year's Freshmen could alleviate some of
the problems of the old one. There are
difficulties with pass- fail policy because
there simply isn't enough documentation
to go on. A lot of supposition on
everyone's part comes into play.
There was a problem with the old
"airtight" system. If this new system can
be flexible enough to allow for the
successful review of individual cases,
there will have been a big improvement.
Too many people were treated unfairly
by the old, unyielding system—students
graduating early, scholarship. applicants,
and so on.
N-L: But didn't the changes in the
pass-fail policy do damage to its original
purpose, which was to give the freshmen
time to adjust by assuring them that their
first semester grades Would never be
released? The new system's flexibility
removes that security, doesn't it?
Colmers: First, you have to go back
and see why the old policy was "airtight"
in the first place. It wasn't done so that
people could screw around for their
entire first semester here. It was done so
that people could get used to being away
from home, the rigors of college life, etc.
Being ,realistic, the medical schools are
interested in only two grades—chemistry
and calculus, so the freshmen have leeway
with the Other grades. Plus those are
courses which continue into the second
semester so you have to do well first
semester in order to be able to continue
successfully. I think the new system, if
people look at it in the right light, still
offers people,the chance to get used to
Ho kins.

N-L: How doyou feel about the
reinstitution of the Dean's List?
Colmers: I don't think it's any good.
Academics should be their own reward. It
will tend to increase competitiveness
here. I just think that if you do well, your
reward should be the knowledge that you
attained. There already are . ancillary
awards. For example, if you do well, your
chances for acceptance at graduate school
are enhance.
N-L: Do you agree with nwst
undergraduates that course offerings here
are insufficient? If you do, what do you
plan to do about it from your position?
Colmers: I do think that certain
departments—which will go unnamed
here—have not offered as many or .as
varied undergraduate courses as they
should, both introductory and 300-level
courses. What to do about it is a
completely different story. I think
undergraduate pressure really is a key
point here. If enough undergraduates go
to a department chairman and ask "Why
isn't there such and such a course? It's
vital to this discipline," something will be
done. They won't remain deaf to
complaints. Courses come from the
professors themselves. Before Dick Cone
of Biophysics offered Physiology last
year, there had never been an
introductory undergraduate course in
that subject in my years here. He found
hithself with Remsen I filled with
students. The same With Botany. It's a
major part of Biology, but until this year
it was never offered to undergraduates at
an introductory level while I've been
here. These courses came out as a
response to the undergraduates.
N-L: Then there is hope, you think?
Colmers: There's hope, but unless
students make their wishes know, and
this can be done through my position, the
CUS or the Student Council, I don't
think there's going to be a major increase
in the number or type of courses offered.
N-L: Are students -correct in their
belief that Deans Owen and Suskind are
somewhat disaffected, oblivious to the
desires of undergraduates?
Conners: I realize that students get
that impression, but I don't think it's
true. I think both of them make an
honest and sincere effort to keep in touch
with what students want.
